chapter.title: Intrusion Prevention
chapter.para:
The Intrusion Prevention Appliance is identified by the
symbol. If the Intrusion Prevention Appliance is not installed, please refer to for installation instructions.

As its name implies, the Intrusion Prevention Appliance prevents known malicious exploits from entering your protected network. It is based on technology from Snort.org. The Snort community maintains information about known exploits, and produces lists of signatures from this information. The Intrusion Prevention Appliance uses rules created from these lists and applies the rules against the traffic entering your network to protect your network.
Note that except for , the configuration of the Intrusion Prevention Appliance is an advanced topic.

sect1.title: Administrative Interface
sect1.para: The Intrusion Prevention Appliance interface has three tabs. The first two tabs, discussed in and , allow the administrator to configure advanced settings. The last tab, , allows the administrator to view intrusion scanning events (see ).

sect2.title: Rule List
sect2.para: The interface for the Rule List tab of the Intrusion Prevention Appliance is shown in .

As stated previously, the Intrusion Prevention Appliance is based on technology from Snort.org. Adding or modifying rules in the syntax defined by Snort.org is an advanced topic, that will not be covered in this manual.

In most cases, an Administrator should only need to alter the block and/or log values of a given rule. Checking the block field of a rule causes the Intrusion Prevention Appliance to enable the rule and block traffic that matches the rule signature. Checking the log field of a rule causes the Intrusion Prevention Appliance to log traffic that matches the rule signature.
The Intrusion Prevention Appliance ships with a default set of rules that have been configured to block malicious exploits. You should only need to disable a rule if that rule blocks traffic from a unique software application that you must use.

sect2.title: Event Log
sect2.para: The Events Log tab is shown in .

The Events tab is another implementation of an Event Log, as described in . The complete list of columns and their meaning is as follows.
Events Tab
timestamp
The time the event took place
action
The action that was taken on the traffic. Valid values are block and pass.
client
The client IP address of the traffic.
reason for action
The rule that was applied to the traffic.
direction
The direction (inbound or outbound) of the traffic. Most Intrusion Prevention Appliance rules only apply to the inbound (into the protected network) direction.
server
The intended server IP address of the traffic.
